summary: Email correspondence between Assistant U.S. Attorney Christian Everdell and defense attorneys regarding discovery issues in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The emails discuss technical problems with evidence production, including missing attachments, metadata issues, and difficulties delivering discovery materials to Maxwell in prison.

events.title: Searches of Epstein residences
events.description: FBI searches of Jeffrey Epstein's residences where evidence including CDs with images was seized.

events.title: Discovery production
events.description: Prosecution provided discovery letter and production of evidence including images seized from Epstein residences.

events.title: Discovery production
events.description: Prosecution provided discovery materials to defense team, referenced in discussion about Bates number gaps.

events.title: Discovery issues correspondence
events.description: Email exchange between prosecution and defense regarding technical problems with evidence production and access for Maxwell in prison.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was incarcerated and had difficulty accessing discovery materials because prison computers couldn't read some files and she couldn't use disks on her laptop.
Over 109,000 emails were produced without attachments, and over 110,000 electronic documents from Epstein's devices had metadata issues with dates appearing after seizure.
Evidence included images seized during 2019 searches of Epstein residences that were not from electronic device extractions and therefore lacked CART numbers.
The defense requested metadata overlays with original metadata for files where metadata indicated creation/modification dates after the devices were seized.
There was a Bates number gap between November 18 and December 18, 2020 productions that the prosecution needed to address.
